info.description:
# Clockify API - AI-Optimized Reference

This OpenAPI specification has been **validated against the live API** and enriched for AI/LLM retrieval.

## 🚀 Quick Start

```bash
# 1. Verify your API key
curl -H "X-Api-Key: YOUR_KEY" https://developer.clockify.me/api/v1/user

# 2. Get your workspaces
curl -H "X-Api-Key: YOUR_KEY" https://developer.clockify.me/api/v1/workspaces
```

## 📋 Key Concepts

| Concept | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Workspace** | Container for all data. Required for most operations |
| **Project** | Work category. Can have tasks, budgets, rates |
| **Task** | Sub-item within a project |
| **Time Entry** | Individual time record. Core tracking entity |
| **Tag** | Label applied to time entries |
| **Client** | Customer associated with projects |

## 🔑 Authentication

Include `X-Api-Key: YOUR_API_KEY` header in all requests.
Get your API key from Clockify Settings → API.

## 📊 Report Endpoints

Report endpoints use a different base URL:
- **Main API**: `https://developer.clockify.me/api`
- **Reports**: `https://developer.clockify.me/report`

## ⚡ Rate Limits

- 10 requests per second per API key
- Use batch endpoints for bulk operations

## 🔗 Common Workflows

### Log Time
1. `GET /v1/workspaces` → Get workspace ID
2. `GET /v1/workspaces/{id}/projects` → Get project ID (optional)
3. `POST /v1/workspaces/{id}/time-entries` → Create entry

### Generate Report
1. Choose endpoint: `/reports/detailed`, `/reports/summary`, `/reports/weekly`
2. POST with `dateRangeStart` and `dateRangeEnd` in body
3. Handle pagination for large datasets

step_1.how: Clockify Settings → API → Generate API Key

x-best-practices: Cache workspace and project IDs - they rarely change
Use pagination for list endpoints (default 50, max 200)
Implement exponential backoff for rate limits (429)
Use reports/detailed for exports instead of fetching all entries
Validate dates are ISO8601 with timezone before sending

401_unauthorized.solution: Verify API key in Clockify Settings → API

causes: Feature not available on your plan
403_forbidden.solution: Check workspace membership and role assignments

404_not_found.solution: Verify IDs are correct 24-char hex strings

409_conflict.solution: Check for existing resources or stop running timer

429_rate_limit.solution: Implement rate limiting. Wait and retry with backoff.

x-request-body-guidance.overview: Understanding minimal vs complete request bodies
rules: Only fields marked 'required' in schema are mandatory
Most endpoints accept minimal bodies with just required fields
Optional fields can be omitted entirely (not null, just absent)
PUT operations typically require all fields (full replacement)
PATCH operations only need fields you're changing (partial update)
Check x-minimal-body for absolute minimum per operation
conditional_requirements: Some fields trigger requirements in other fields
Example: auditFilter requires specific null values

tags.name: Entity Changes: Use cases
tags.description:
This section provides a step-by-step guide that shows you how to use the Entity Changes API to keep your system up to date with time entry data, including custom field values, without re-downloading everything each time.

> ### 💡 Note
> Currently, this guide covers only one use case (custom field changes), but we plan to add more in the future.  

# Use Case: Keep Custom Field Values in Sync - Entity Changes Based on Detailed Report

This use case describes how to retrieve a full set of data (via the Detailed Report), then use incremental updates of custom fields or [other supported types](#tag/Entity-Changes:-Use-cases/Use-Case:-Keep-Custom-Field-Values-in-Sync-Entity-Changes-Based-on-Detailed-Report/Supported-types) to stay in sync, including new, updated or deleted records.  

## Step 1: Get Initial Data Using the Detailed Report

Start by fetching time entries for a specified date range using the Detailed Report API. This is your baseline data (base dataset). 

Below is an example that fetches data from `May 1 to May 20, 2025`.

Example: Get data from May 1 to May 20, 2025.

  * **Use the `curl` command below:**
```
curl --location 'https://{API_BASE_URL}/report/workspaces/{WORKSPACE_ID}/reports/detailed' \
--header 'Accept: application/json' \
--data '{
    "dateRangeStart": "2025-05-01T00:00:00.000Z",
    "dateRangeEnd": "2025-05-20T23:59:59.999Z"
}'
```

  * **Sample response:**
```json
    {
      "timeentries": [
        {
          "_id": "1",
          "description": "Time entry 1",
          "timeInterval": {
            "start": "2025-05-18T01:00:00Z",
            "end": "2025-05-18T09:00:00.000Z"
          },
          "customFields": [
            {
              "customFieldId": "6808e9a6b77db953ea0d3f73",
              "value": "custom field value 1"
            }
          ]
        },
        {
          "_id": "2",
          "description": "Time entry 2",
          "timeInterval": {
            "start": "2025-05-19T01:00:00Z",
            "end": "2025-05-19T09:00:00.000Z"
          },
          "customFields": [
            {
              "customFieldId": "6808e9a6b77db953ea0d3f73",
              "value": "Custom field value 2"
            }
          ]
        }
      ]
    }
```

The response contains a list of time entries with all current custom field values. 
Save this in your database. You’ll use it to apply future changes

> ### 💡 Note
> After this, you don’t need to fetch the full report again. Simply use the following steps to apply the changes.  

## Step 2: Retrieve Created Custom Field Values

Fetch any new custom field values added after the date range you fetched in Step 1.

Example: Get newly created values after May 20, 2025.

> ### 💡 Note
> For the API specification see [Created entities - Custom field values ](#tag/Entity-changes-(Experimental)/operation/getCreatedEntityInfo)


* **Use the `curl` command below:**

```bash
curl -X GET "https://{API_BASE_URL}/v1/workspaces/{WORKSPACE_ID}/entities/created?type=TIME_ENTRY_CUSTOM_FIELD_VALUE&start=2025-05-21T00:00:00Z&end=2025-05-22T00:00:00Z&limit=30&page=1"
```
* **Sample response:**
```json
  [
    {
      "auditMetadata": {
        "updatedAt": "2025-05-21T04:00:00Z",
        "createdAt": "2025-05-21T03:00:00Z"
      },
      "documentType": "TIME_ENTRY_CUSTOM_FIELD_VALUE",
      "id": "...",
      "customFieldId": "6808e9a6b77db953ea0d3f85",
      "timeEntryId": "3",
      "value": "Custom field value 3"
        "sourceType": "TIMEENTRY"
    }
  ]
```

The response shows only newly created custom field values. 

Each record has a timeEntryId, so you know which entry to update.

Add these new values to your stored data.

> ### 💡 Note
> Run this daily, weekly, or as often as your app needs updates.


## Step 3: Retrieve Updated Custom Field Values
**Next**, fetch custom field values that were updated after your original data.

Example: Get updates after May 20, 2025.

> ### 💡 Note
> For API specification see [Updated entities - Custom field values ](#tag/Entity-changes-(Experimental)/operation/getUpdatedEntityInfo)     

  * **Use the `curl` command below:**


```bash
curl -X GET "https://{API_BASE_URL}/v1/workspaces/{WORKSPACE_ID}/entities/updated?type=TIME_ENTRY_CUSTOM_FIELD_VALUE&start=2025-05-21T00:00:00Z&end=2025-05-22T00:00:00Z&limit=30&page=1"
```
* **Sample response:**
```json
  [
    {
      "auditMetadata": {
        "updatedAt": "2025-05-21T04:51:20Z",
        "createdAt": "2025-05-19T04:51:10Z"
      },
      "documentType": "TIME_ENTRY_CUSTOM_FIELD_VALUE",
      "id": "...",
      "customFieldId": "6808e9a6b77db953ea0d3f73",
      "timeEntryId": "2",
      "value": "Custom field value 2 - Updated"
        "sourceType": "TIMEENTRY"
    }
  ]
```
The response shows only updated values within the specified date range. 

Updates are linked to their timeEntryId.

Update the matching records in your database.

> ### 💡 Note
>  If a record was both created and updated in the same date range, it will only appear in the /created response, not /updated.

## Step 4: Retrieve or Identify Deleted Custom Field Values
Finally, handle deletions. Use this step to retrieve any custom field values that were deleted after your initial date range and remove them from your own database. 

Example: Get deletions after May 20, 2025.

> ### 💡 Note
> For more information about this API, see [Deleted entities - Custom field values ](#tag/Entity-changes-(Experimental)/operation/getDeletedEntityInfo)

* **Use the `curl` command below:**
```
curl -X GET "https://{API_BASE_URL}/v1/workspaces/{WORKSPACE_ID}/entities/deleted?type=TIME_ENTRY_CUSTOM_FIELD_VALUE&start=2025-05-21T00:00:00Z&end=2025-05-22T00:00:00Z&limit=30&page=1"
```

* **Sample response:**
```json
  [
    {
      "id": "...",
      "deletionBinId": "....",
      "deletedAt": "2025-05-21T23:15:54.790Z",
      "documentType": "TIME_ENTRY_CUSTOM_FIELD_VALUE",
      "document": {
        "customFieldId": "6808e9a6b77db953ea0d3f73",
        "timeEntryId": "1",
        "value": "custom field value 1",
        "sourceType": "TIMEENTRY"
      }
    }
  ]
```

The response contains references to the deleted values (e.g. timeEntryId and field ID). 

Remove or archive these records in your system.

> ### 💡 Note 
> If a value was created and deleted in the same date range, it will not show up in the deleted results.

## Supported types

  This guide focuses on tracking custom field values `(type=TIME_ENTRY_CUSTOM_FIELD_VALUE)`.

  The same approach can be applied to other data types. Simply change the type parameter in your requests and you can use the same steps for all supported types:

  * `TIME_ENTRY`
  * `TIME_ENTRY_RATE`
  * `TIME_ENTRY_CUSTOM_FIELD_VALUE`

  We may support more types in the future as the system evolves.

x-codeSamples.label: Python
x-codeSamples.source:
import requests

headers = {
    "X-Api-Key": "YOUR_API_KEY",
    "Content-Type": "application/json"
}

url = "https://developer.clockify.me/api/v1/user"
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())

get.description:
Retrieves the currently authenticated user's complete profile.

**FIRST CALL TO MAKE** - Verifies API key and gets essential IDs:
- `id` - Your user ID (for time entries, reports)
- `activeWorkspace` - Default workspace ID (for most API calls)
- `email`, `name` - Profile information
- `settings` - User preferences

**No parameters required** - Uses API key for authentication.
x-ai-tips: Cache responses to minimize API calls
Call this endpoint first to verify API key and get workspace ID
Cache user ID and activeWorkspace for session
x-api-tips: Use ETags or If-Modified-Since headers where supported for efficient caching

get.description:

Returns workspaces where user is a member with role and feature info.
Most free users have 1 workspace; paid plans allow multiple.

**Response fields**:
- `id` - Workspace ID for API calls
- `name` - Display name
- `features` - List of enabled features
- `featureSubscriptionType` - Plan: FREE, BASIC, PRO, ENTERPRISE

**Addon context**: Filters to webhooks for your integration.
**Workspace ID**: Get from `GET /v1/user` response field `activeWorkspace`.
x-ai-tips: Cache responses to minimize API calls

Verify X-Clockify-Signature header on webhook callbacks
Implement idempotency - same event may be sent multiple times
Requires X-Api-Key header with valid API key

get.description:
Lists approval requests with optional filters.

**Query params**:
- `status` - PENDING, APPROVED, REJECTED, WITHDRAWN
- `page`, `page-size` - Pagination

**For managers**: See pending requests to approve.
**For users**: Track your submitted requests.

Implement pagination logic to fetch all results
Use page-size=200 (max) for faster bulk retrieval
x-api-tips: Use ETags or If-Modified-Since headers where supported for efficient caching
Default page-size is 50, max is 200
Requires X-Api-Key header with valid API key

parameters.description: Flag to toggle on/off strict search mode. When set to true, search by name will only return projects whose name exactly matches the string value given for the 'name' parameter. When set to false, results will also include projects whose name contain the string value, but could be longer than the string value itself. For example, if there is a project with the name 'applications', and the search value is 'app', setting strict-name-search to true will not return that project in the results, whereas setting it to false will.

delete.description:

- All time entries logged to this project
- All tasks in this project
- All project settings and memberships

**Safer alternative**: Archive instead (PUT with archived: true).

parameters.description: Flag to toggle on/off strict search mode. When set to true, search by name only will return tasks whose name exactly matches the string value given for the 'name' parameter. When set to false, results will also include tasks whose name contain the string value, but could be longer than the string value itself. For example, if there is a task with the name 'applications', and the search value is 'app', setting strict-name-search to true will not return that task in the results, whereas setting it to false will.
parameters.name: strict-name-search

schema.description: Flag to toggle on/off strict search mode. When set to true, search by name only will return tasks whose name exactly matches the string value given for the 'name' parameter. When set to false, results will also include tasks whose name contain the string value, but could be longer than the string value itself. For example, if there is a task with the name 'applications', and the search value is 'app', setting strict-name-search to true will not return that task in the results, whereas setting it to false will.

parameters.description: true = active/open items only (default), false = done/closed only

post.description:
Creates a new time entry or starts a timer.

**Required**: `start` (ISO8601 with timezone)

**TWO MODES**:
1. **Completed entry**: Include `start` AND `end`
2. **Running timer**: Only `start` (no end)

- `projectId` - Project to log to
- `taskId` - Task (requires projectId)
- `tagIds` - Array of tag IDs
- `billable` - Mark as billable

**Response**: Array of user objects with membership info.

- `userId`: Get from `GET /v1/user` → `id` or workspace users list

post.x-ai-hint: Assign role to user. sourceType rules are CRITICAL.
post.description:
Assigns a role to a user in the workspace.

**CRITICAL BUSINESS RULES**:

1. **WORKSPACE_ADMIN** (full admin):
   - `entityId` = workspaceId
   - DO NOT include `sourceType`

2. **TEAM_MANAGER on user** (direct):
   - `entityId` = userId being managed
   - DO NOT include `sourceType`

3. **TEAM_MANAGER on group** (group-based):
   - `entityId` = groupId
   - MUST include `sourceType: "GROUP"`

**Common mistake**: Including/omitting sourceType incorrectly causes 400.

  -H "X-Api-Key: YOUR_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"name": "Example"}'

post.description:

- `name` - Webhook identifier
- `url` - Your HTTPS endpoint
- `triggerSourceType` - Events to trigger on

**Trigger types**:
- NEW_TIME_ENTRY, TIME_ENTRY_UPDATED, TIME_ENTRY_DELETED
- NEW_PROJECT, PROJECT_UPDATED
- TIMER_STOPPED
- NEW_CLIENT, NEW_TASK, NEW_TAG

delete.description:

**Endpoint**: `DELETE /v1/workspaces/{workspaceId}/shared-reports/{id}`
**Category**: Shared Report

⚠️ **Warning**: This action may be irreversible.
**Response**: Returns empty response on success (204) or deleted resource.

**Path Parameters**:
- `workspaceId`: Get from `GET /v1/user` → `activeWorkspace`
- `id`: Resource identifier (24-char hex string)

strictSearch.description: Flag to toggle on/off strict search mode. When set to true, search by invoice number only will return invoices whose number exactly matches the string value given for the 'invoiceNumber' parameter. When set to false, results will also include invoices whose number contain the string value, but could be longer than the string value itself. For example, if there is an invoice with the number '123456', and the search value is '123', setting strict-name-search to true will not return that invoice in the results, whereas setting it to false will.

WorkspaceSettingsDtoV1.description:
Workspace settings also include Time Duration Format settings.

Setting Time Duration Format by changing the boolean fields
decimalFormat and trackTimeDownToSecond is now deprecated.

Time Duration Format can be set by durationFormat enum field.

Three different Time Duration modes will still map the boolean fields:

    1. Full (hh:mm:ss) -> decimalFormat = false, trackTimeDownToSecond = true,

    2. Compact (h:mm) -> decimalFormat = false, trackTimeDownToSecond = false,

    3. Decimal (h:hh) -> decimalFormat = true, trackTimeDownToSecond = true
